```{python}
#| label: build-meme
#| include: false

from step1_prepare_image import prepare_image
from step2_create_stipple import create_stipple
from step4_create_block_letter import create_block_letter_s
from step5_create_masked import create_masked_stipple
from create_meme import create_statistics_meme

# 1. Reality: prepare my own image
img_path = "BiasChallenge.jpg"
gray_image = prepare_image(img_path)

# 2. Your Model: blue-noise stipple
stipple_image, samples = create_stipple(
    gray_image,
    percentage=0.08,
    sigma=0.9,
    content_bias=0.9,
    noise_scale_factor=0.12,
    extreme_downweight=0.45,
    extreme_threshold_low=0.20,
    extreme_threshold_high=0.80,
    extreme_sigma=0.10,
)

# 3. Selection Bias: bold S mask
h, w = gray_image.shape
block_letter = create_block_letter_s(
    height=h,
    width=w,
    letter="S",
    font_size_ratio=0.9,
)

# 4. Estimate: apply mask to remove points in a pattern
masked_stipple = create_masked_stipple(
    stipple_img=stipple_image,
    mask_img=block_letter,
    threshold=0.5,
)

# 5. Build final 4-panel meme
output_path = "output/selection_bias_meme.png"

create_statistics_meme(
    original_img=gray_image,
    stipple_img=stipple_image,
    block_letter_img=block_letter,
    masked_stipple_img=masked_stipple,
    output_path=output_path,
    dpi=170,
    background_color="white",
)
```

<div class="explainer-lab">
  <div class="explainer-lab-title">Why this shows selection bias</div>
  <p>
    The meme starts with the true picture (<strong>Reality</strong>) and turns it into a stippled sample of dots that acts as my <strong>model</strong> of the data.  
    The bold <strong>S</strong> removes any dots that land inside it, creating a clear, non‑random missing‑data pattern instead of random noise.  
    The final panel (<strong>Estimate</strong>) is what we would see after this biased missingness, where the S‑shaped gap pushes the picture away from reality in the same way selection bias can twist real statistical results.
  </p>
